query: Can you define a monomial ideal that has krull dimension 4?
response: To define a monomial ideal with Krull dimension 4, you could use a polynomial ring in four variables. A simple example is the ideal generated by four variables, say, \( I = (x_1, x_2, x_3, x_4) \) in the ring \( R = k[x_1, x_2, x_3, x_4] \) where \( k \) is a field. This ideal is monomial and has Krull dimension 4 because the dimension of a polynomial ring in \( n \) variables is \( n \). For more specific construction, you may also employ techniques in Macaulay2 to compute the dimension and verify the properties of the ideal created.
references: [functions\ideal-doc.m2] convert a monomial ideal to an ideal

result.headline: convert a monomial ideal to an ideal
convert a module to an ideal
compute the projective dimension of a module

result.keys: hilbertfunction hilbertfunction,list,ring hilbertfunction,zz,ring hilbertfunction,list,module hilbertfunction,zz,module hilbertfunction,list,ideal hilbertfunction,zz,ideal hilbertfunction,ring hilbertfunction,module hilbertfunction,ideal headline the hilbert function usage hilbertfunction(d,x inputs d:{zz,list} -- of integers specifying a degree (or multidegree m:{ring,ideal,module outputs :zz the dimension of the degree @samp "d"@ part of @samp "m"@. for an ideal, the corresponding quotient ring is used. description text in the following example, compare the rank of the source of the basis map to the number provided by @samp "hilbertfunction"@. example r = qq[x,y,z, degrees=>{3:{1,1}}]; hilbertfunction({3,3}, r basis({3,3},r text the standard meaning of subscripts on functions permits a simpler syntax to be used. example hilbertfunction_{3,3} r text here is a singly graded example. example r = qq[x,y,z]; hilbertfunction({3}, r hilbertfunction(3, r text here is an example with a module. example r = qq[a..d, degrees=>{4:{1,1}}]; m = coker matrix {{a,c,d},{c,b,d hilbertfunction({2,2}, m b = basis({2,2},m numgens source b text here is an example with an ideal. example r = qq[a..f, degrees=>{6:{1,1}}]; i = ideal (a*b, c*d, e*f); hilbertfunction({2,2}, i s = r/i; basis({2,2},s text if @samp "d"@ is not given, then a function is returned that will accept different values of @samp "d"@. example r = qq[a..d]; i = monomialcurveideal(r, {1,2,3}); h = hilbertfunction i h 1 h 2 caveat it can be much faster to compute a basis for the desired degree, because hilbertfunction works by expanding the hilbert series to a sufficiently high order, thus, in effect, computing many values of the hilbert function simultaneously. if several values of the hilbert function are desired, it is best to compute the ones of higher degree first, so the expansion will be done to sufficiently high order at the first attempt, and thus be done just once. seealso degreesring reducehilbert poincare complexes :: poincaren hilbertseries hilbertpolynomial numgens symbol _, function, thing
